questions.text: Which imaging modality is the gold standard for identifying and quantifying atherosclerotic stenoses of the cerebral arteries?

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about cerebral edema after acute ischemic stroke?

options.label: A
options.text: 5 and 10% of patients develop enough cerebral edema to cause obtundation or brain herniation

options.label: B
options.text: Edema peaks on day 10 but can cause mass effect for a year

options.label: C
options.text: The larger the infarct, the greater the likelihood that edema will develop

options.label: D
options.text: Water restriction and IV mannitol may be used to raise the serum osmolarity

questions.correct_answer: B. Edema peaks on day 10 but can cause mass effect for a year
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Edema peaks on day 10 but can cause mass effect for a year Edema peaks on day 10 but can cause mass effect for a year is an incorrect statement about cerebral edema after acute ischemic stroke. Edema peaks on the second or third day but can cause mass effects for ~10 days.

Highyeild:

Cerebral edema after acute ischemic stroke- Between 5 and 10% of patients develop enough cerebral edema to cause obtundation and brain herniation. Edema peaks on the second or third day but can cause a mass effect for ~10 days. The larger the infarct, the greater the likelihood that clinically significant edema will develop. Water restriction and IV mannitol may be used to raise the serum osmolarity, but hypovolemia should be avoided because this may contribute to hypotension and worsening infarction. A combined analysis of three randomized European trials of hemicraniectomy (craniotomy and temporary removal of part of the skull ) shows that hemicraniectomy reduces mortality by 50% , and the clinical outcomes of survivors are significantly improved. Older patients (age >60 years) benefit less but still significantly. The size of the diffusion-weighted imaging volume of brain infarction during the acute stroke is a predictor of future deterioration requiring hemicraniectomy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C, and D are correct statements about cerebral edema after acute ischemic stroke . Option A. 5 and 10% of patients develop enough cerebral edema to cause obtundation or brain herniation- Uncontrolled cerebral edema may result in increased intracranial pressure and acute herniation syndromes that can result in permanent neurologic deficits. Option C. The larger the infarct, the greater the likelihood that edema will develop- This is because the infarcted area is exposed to systemic pressures and an increase in the blood pressur e will tend to open the blood-brain barrier and drive the formation of extracellular edema. Option D. Water restriction and IV mannitol may be used to raise the serum osmolarity- this will prevent progress of oedema but hypovolemia should be avoided because this may contribute to hypotension and worsening infarction.

questions.text: What is the route for Paradoxical embolization in embolic stroke?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PFO or ASD Paradoxical embolization occurs when venous thrombi migrate to the arterial circulation, usually via a patent foramen ovale (PFO) or atrial septal defect.

Highyeild:

Paradoxical embolization- Occurs when venous thrombi migrate to the arterial circulation, usually via a patent foramen ovale (PFO) or atrial septal defect. Diagnosis- Bubble-contrast echocardiography (IV injection of agitated saline coupled with either transthoracic or transesophageal echocardiography ) can demonstrate a right-to-left cardiac shunt , revealing the conduit for paradoxical embolization. Alternatively, a right-to-left shunt is implied if immediately following IV injection of agitated saline, the ultrasound signature of bubbles is observed during transcranial Doppler insonation of the MCA; pulmonary arteriovenous malformations should be considered if this test is positive yet an echocardiogram fails to reveal an intracardiac shunt. Both techniques are highly sensitive for the detection of right-to-left shunts. Etiology- Venous clot, fat and tumour emboli, bacterial endocarditis, IV air, and amniotic fluid emboli at childbirth. The importance of a patent foramen ovale (PFO) as a cause of stroke is debated, particularly because they are present in ~15% of the general population. The presence of a venous source of embolus, most commonly a deep-venous thrombus, may provide confirmation of the importance of a patent foramen ovale (PFO) with an accompanying right-to-left shunt in a particular case. Meta-analysis of three recent randomized trials reported a hazard ratio of 0.41 for recurrent stroke (about a 1% per year absolute reduction) using percutaneous occlusion devices in patients with no other explanation for their stroke. Guidelines now endorse patent foramen ovale (PFO) closure with percutaneous devices after consultation with a neurologist and a cardiologist.

questions.text: What is the finding seen in the following MR angiogram of cerebral circulation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aneurysm of MCA MR angiogram shows a giant aneurysm (Abnormal dilation of an artery due to weakening of vessel wall )at the middle cerebral artery bifurcation (arrow).

Highyeild:

Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) - Causes- Head trauma (the most common cause of SAH) Rupture of a saccular aneurysm (Most common non-traumatic cause) Approximately 85% of aneurysms occur in the anterior circulation , mostly on the circle of Willis. Other causes Bleeding from a vascular malformation Arteriovenous malformation Dural arteriovenous fistula Extension into the subarachnoid space from a primary intracerebral haemorrhage. Idiopathic SAHs Localized to the perimesencephalic cisterns Benign have a venous or capillary source Angiography is unrevealing. Pathology of Saccular (Berry) aneurysms:- Saccular (Berry) aneurysms occur at the bifurcations of the large to medium-sized intracranial arteries → rupture is into the subarachnoid space in the basal cisterns and often into the parenchyma of the adjacent brain. As an aneurysm develops, it typically forms a neck with a dome. The length of the neck and the size of the dome vary greatly and are factors that are important in planning neurosurgical obliteration or endovascular embolization. The arterial internal elastic lamina disappears at the base neck. of the The media thins and connective tissue replaces smooth-muscle cells. At the site of rupture (most often the dome) the wall thins , and the tear that allows bleeding is often < 0.5 mm long. Aneurysm size and site are important in predicting the risk of rupture- Greater risk of rupture Diameter >7 mm at the top of the basilar artery at the origin of the posterior communicating artery .

Hemorrhagic stroke in ACA territory-hemorrhagic stroke will show leakage of dye outside lumen entering in the brain parenchyma from the involved artery . MR angiogram of the circle of Willis showing a large hematoma obscuring the M1 segment of the left middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: Patient, who is having risk factors for stroke, developed features of sensory disturbance, motor weakness and non-fluent aphasia. Which of the following parts of the middle cerebral artery is likely to be affected?
questions.correct_answer: D. Proximal superior division of MCA
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Proximal superior division of MCA As the patient has sensory, and motor disturbance with Non-fluent aphasia the likely affected cerebral artery is the Proximal superior division of MCA

Highyeild:

The proximal MCA (M1 segment) gives rise to penetrating branches (termed lenticulostriate arteries) that supply the putamen, outer globus pallidus, posterior limb of the internal capsule , adjacent corona radiata, and most of the caudate nucleus. In the Sylvian fissure, the MCA in most patients divides into superior and inferior divisions (M2 branches). Branches of the inferior division supply the inferior parietal and temporal cortex(M4 branch), and those from the superior division ( M3 branch )supply the frontal and superior parietal cortex. Inferior division of MCA occlusion- Dominant hemisphere→Wernicke’s Aphasia No weakness/ hemianesthesia Homonymous superior Quadrantanopia Dominant hemisphere-Gerstmann syndrome Non-dominant hemisphere-Spatial agnosia, hemineglect. Superior division of MCA occlusion- Broca’s aphasia C/L hemiplegia-dominant MCA lesion]C/L weakness-Hand and arm> Leg: Brachial syndrome Face weakness Sensory loss: Hand and arm >Leg Homonymous inferior quadrantanopia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.Inferior division of MCA -will have fluent aphasia without weakness . Option B. Entire MCA blocked at the origin -If entire MCA is occluded at its origin and the distal collaterals are limited the clinical findings are contralateral hemiplegia, hemianesthesia, homonymous hemianopia, gaze preference to the ipsilateral side Occlusion of lenticulostriate vessel -This will produce a pure motor stroke or sensory stroke contralateral to the lesion.

questions.text: The patient, 47 years old, had a case of acute ischaemic stroke 12 hours ago. Primary management was done in the patient. According to anti-thrombotic treatment guidelines, all of the following are beneficial to the patient except
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anticoagulation The patient has a case of acute ischaemic stroke. Primary management was done. However, in the treatment of acute ischaemic stroke , anticoagulants have minimal or no role . Numerous clinical trials have failed to demonstrate any benefit of routine anticoagulation in the primary treatment of cerebral ischemia. Therefore the routine use of heparin and other anticoagulants for ischaemic stroke is not warranted.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.Platelet inhibition - Aspirin is the only antiplatelet drug that has been proven to be effective for the acute treatment of ischaemic stroke . Also, there are several antiplatelet agents have been proven for the secondary prevention of stroke . Hence this option is true. Option C. Stroke centers -Stroke centres use clinical pathways and staff are dedicated to stroke patients . This can be beneficial to the patient. It can reduce the mortality rate of patient care in stroke units followed by rehabilitation services improves neurologic outcomes and reduces mortality. The use of clinical pathways and staff dedicated to stroke patients can improve care. Option D. rehabilitation -Proper rehabilitation of stroke patients includes early physical, occupational and speech therapy . Hence this is also beneficial to stroke patients because this also aims at reducing the mortality rates of the patients

questions.text: Which lobe can the lesion be localized in a patient with a complaint of blindness in both eyes but normal light and accommodation reflexes in both eyes?

Occipital Occipital Lobe Lesions can cause complaints of blindness in both eyes but normal light and accommodation reflexes in both eyes are called Cortical blindness.

Highyeild:

Ventral view of the brain, correlating patterns of visual field loss with the sites of lesions in the visual pathway.By convention, the visual fields are always recorded with the left eye’s field on the left and the right eye’s field on the right, just as the patient sees the world.
